subject: Japanese Economy Minister says Japan will soon be out of deflationary situation
BoJ Governor Kuroda is to appear in parliament from 00:40GMT
BoJ Governor Kuroda is to appear in parliament from 00:40GMT
PREVIEW: RBA minutes from the February meeting where the central bank kept rates on hold at the record low of 1.50% as expected, due at 0030GMT/1830CST/0830HKT
content: RBA will be publishing minutes from their latest meeting today where expectations are for the central bank to strike a neutral tone. Philip Lowe, the RBA governor, has recently played down expectations for a hike in the near term, saying that the timing of a move “will depend on the extent and pace of progress that we make in reducing the unemployment rate and having inflation return to target”. He added that he expects this progress to be only gradual, indicating that the board does not see a strong case for a hike in the near term. Economists as CBA say that the RBA’s recent communication has struck a helpful balance between taking an optimistic stance on the economic outlook while managing to hose down interest rate expectations. The minutes are expected to echo these recent communications, signalling that rate hikes are still some way off and when they do come, are expected to be at a gradual pace

subject: PM May is said to have contingency plan to withhold payments of the GBP 40bln Brexit bill if EU leaders backtrack on their post Brexit free trade deal commitments

subject: RANsquawk audio and headlines closed for the session - The desk will reopen at 2200GMT/1700EST
BOE Governor Carney makes no comments on current monetary policy and the economic outlook
UBS Weekly FX Flows: Safe-haven inflows extended, EUR & USD sold ahead of this week's minutes
content:
- JPY and CHF remained as the two most bought currencies in G10, global risk sentiment gradually recovered from the recent sell-off.
- Amid the safe-haven bid, cyclical currencies  such  as  GBP,  AUD  and  NZD,  saw  outflows.  
- GBP was the most sold among majors, recording outflows for a fifth straight week during a week when January inflation came out higher than expected but retail sales missed consensus expectations.
- Ahead of this week's ECB and FOMC minutes, EUR and USD were both net sold. 
- Also, notably, as shown in the EURNOK flows chart below, asset managers and hedge funds' net  flows  through  EURNOK  have  parted  ways  in  the  last  few  weeks. 
- In EM, KRW inflows have grown even bigger than in the previous week, while MXN swung back to large outflows.

subject: Luis De Guindos has been confirmed as the nominee for ECB Vice President
FX Daily Wrap: rangy US holiday trade
content: Minimal deviation from early ranges, with Eur/Usd and Cable both inching a bit further above 1.2400 and 1.4000 respectively on an upbeat Buba monthly report (booming German economy) and positive Brexit comments (Australian Foreign Minister open to a free trade agreement with the UK), but unable to pull away convincingly and drifting back down again. On the charts, nearest supports for Eur/Usd and Cable come in around 1.2371-76 (Fib and DMA) and 1.3920, and resistance at 1.2555 and 1.4151. Meanwhile, Usd/Jpy meandered within an extremely narrow band near the top of wider 106.10-65 parameters and mostly around the 106.50 level that is essentially also on a key chart Fib. The Aud just kept its head above 0.7900 vs the Greenback and its other G10 counterparts ahead of several potential risk events starting with a speech by RBA’s Bullock later today, the latest policy meeting minutes on Tuesday and wage data on Wednesday when a very large 0.7950 option expiry strike runs off (3.2 bn). On the flow side, offers are reported at 0.7940 and in chart terms the 20 DMA is at 0.7956. Trading volumes and conditions have been impacted by Asian, US and Canadian holidays not to mention the usual Monday lethargy, but the potential more decent market moves and price action ratchets up as the week unfolds given FOMC and ECB minutes, the BoE’s QIR testimony plus some key data and survey releases.

Bunds: a bit more bearish flow on a very bullish Buba
content: Only a marginal new Eurex low at 158.27, but this time amidst some fundamental impetus in the form of a very upbeat bulletin from the German CB (economy extremely robust and pay seen rising faster ahead vs previous years). Turnover remains relatively light at under 140k lots, and in fact price movement is virtually non-existent as the 10 year debt future inched down another tick or so from the previous 158.61 settlement and is now holding fire again. However, some curve steepening seen today with a decent clip of Schatz bought earlier (4k lots at 111.850) despite looming 2 year supply.

subject: Bundesbank report: Recent rise in forward rates partially based on Jan release of minutes from ECB’s Dec governing council meeting, adding that German economy is “booming”

Angola to export 1.51mln bpd of crude oil in 47 cargoes in April; according to provisional programme
EU MID-SESSION UPDATE: European bourses flat ahead of US holiday. Reckitt Benckiser and Daimler notable laggards. USD fights back
content:
EU bourses trade with little in the way of firm direction (Eurostoxx 50 flat) after erasing opening gains in what’s been a quiet session thus far ahead of the US holiday. In terms of sector specifics, consumer staples have been softer throughout the morning following a disappointing earnings update from Reckitt Benckiser (-5%) which has sent their shares to the bottom of the FSTE 100 and on track for their worst daily performance since 2015. In sympathy, Nestle (-0.9%) are also seen lower and subsequently has placed some weight on the SMI (-0.2%). Elsewhere, other notable movers include Daimler (-2%) who have fallen victim to reports in German press that the Co. included emissions-cheating software on their diesel models.

The DXY appears to have established a firmer foothold above the 89.000 level, but the Greenback is struggling to break a few big figures and extend its recovery from last week’s multi year lows in holiday-thinned markets (several Asian centres still shut and the US out for Presidents’ Day). Eur/Usd has dipped below 1.2400 and Cable just under 1.4000, but both pairs continue come back strong suggesting decent demand if not solid bidding interest for the single currency and Sterling respectively. Eur/Usd also remains technically bullish while above its 21 and 10 DMAs (1.2376 and 1.2355 respectively) and key Fib supports (50% at 1.2371 and 68% at 1.2340), with buying interest also touted at 1.2350. Meanwhile, Usd/Jpy has bounced off overnight lows and further above the 106.00 handle within a 106.10-65 range, but remains bearish having closed sub-106.51 last week (key Fib) and ahead of its 106.73 descending 100 HMA. Elsewhere in the G10 arena, the Aud is outperforming back above 0.7900 vs its US counterpart ahead of key local events, like RBA minutes and wage data, while a mega 0.7950 (3.2 bn) option expiry on Wednesday may also be exerting some upside influence. In terms of positioning, latest weekly CTFC data shows another reduction in Usd net shorts by spec accounts, while Eur and Gbp longs were trimmed again.

More downside on Eurex where the 10 year German bond and other Eurozone debt futures have extended losses, former to 31 ticks at a fresh 158.30 low. Interestingly the latest leg down has not come alongside or coincided with any further stock gains, so rather than asset-switching or related flows the selling in fixed looks independent. Indeed, French OATs, Italian BTPs and Spanish Bonos are all on the rack, in stark contrast to Greek bonds that are revelling in bullish upgrade trade. Gilts are holding up better, and actually rebounded further from early Liffe lows to a fresk intraday peak at 121.22 (-6 ticks vs -23 ticks at one stage) before fading again, while USTs are basically side-lined and idling in quiet overnight trade.

In the commodities complex, WTI and Brent crude futures trade higher after WTI reclaimed USD 62/bbl during Asia-Pac trade with energy newsflow otherwise particularly light. That said, markets will be monitoring the geopolitical landscape after Israeli PM Netanyahu labelled Iran as “the greatest threat to our world”, with the Saudi Arabian foreign minister claiming that Iran is the “most dangerous nation for cyber attacks”. In the metals complex, spot gold trades with little in the way of firm direction after largely tracking fluctuations in the USD. Elsewhere, copper prices in London have been hampered by the firmer USD with price action otherwise relatively contained given Chinese participants away from market.

subject: Fixed Income: Bunds underperforming Gilts
content: More downside on Eurex where the 10 year German bond and other Eurozone debt futures have extended losses, former to 31 ticks at a fresh 158.30 low. Interestingly the latest leg down has not come alongside or coincided with any further stock gains, so rather than asset-switching or related flows the selling in fixed looks independent. Indeed, French OATs, Italian BTPs and Spanish Bonos are all on the rack, in stark contrast to Greek bonds that are revelling in bullish upgrade trade. Gilts are holding up better, and actually rebounded further from early Liffe lows to a fresk intraday peak at 121.22 (-6 ticks vs -23 ticks at one stage) before fading again, while USTs are basically side-lined and idling in quiet overnight trade.

UK DEBT AND STIR FUTURES: weaker tone in line with peers
content: Gilts have returned to Liffe on the back foot and largely tracking counterparts as Bunds dip a bit further and on tad better turnover to 158.40 (-21 ticks on the day), with the 10 year UK benchmark testing support/bids just ahead of the 121.00 level again within an early 121.05-121.16 range vs last Friday’s 121.28 close. Similarly, the 3 month strip is mostly softer (1-2 ticks adrift beyond the front month March contract) amidst another uptick in equities and an improvement in risk appetite overall. A blank slate in terms of domestic data today, and market holidays in Asia and the US dampening trade, but for those still around later in the day BoE Governor Carney will be making a speech and a text is to be published.

subject: Bunds: risk-on sentiment weighs on core fixed
content: A weaker, albeit very low key start to the week for the 10 year German debt future, as holidays in Asia and the US adversely impact trading volumes (turnover only around 12.5k lots so far) . However, further gains in global stock markets are undermining core bonds amidst a broad unwind of the pre-weekend bid that saw benchmark futures bounce off recent lows and corresponding yields pull back from their peaks accordingly. Bunds currently nudging the lower end of a tight 158.43-53 Eurex range, 10 year cash rate hovering around 0.72%. As usual a relatively bare Monday agenda in terms of data, but the ECB is in focus with the new VP due to be announced and Latvia’s representative in the news amidst fraud allegations.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Daimler under investigation regarding the use of illegal software to cheat emission tests
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

19th February 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian bourses get off to a firm start to the week, with the ASX 200 (+0.6%), Nikkei 225 (+2.0%) and KOSPI (+0.4%) trading with modest gains. ASX 200 has been supported by strength observed in financial, subsequently offsetting the losses in Woodside Petroleum (-6%) following AUD 2.5bln capital raising. South Korean participants have return from their elongated break to catch up with last week’s global equity recovery. Nikkei 225 has been buoyed by encouraging trade data, whereby exports rose for a 14th consecutive month. Markets have been somewhat quiet given the Lunar New Year holiday with Chinese markets out of action until Wednesday (HK reopens tomorrow)

Very quiet session in the fixed income space with Japanese yields relatively flat across the curve. Elsewhere, Aussie yields have shown a slight bull flattening bias today. AU-US 10 spreads (+0.1bps) continue to remain at the tightest levels since 1998.

US

EQUITIES: SPX +0.1% at 2739, DJI +0.1% at 25281, NDX -0.1% at 6785

Top sectors: Healthcare +0.9%, Telecoms +0.9%, Utilities +0.9%

Bottom sectors: Cons Disc -0.3%, Materials -0.1% Energy -0.1%

SPX prints its sixth straight day of gains, as traders question whether the recent VIX-inspired sell-off can actually be considered anything close to “market turmoil,” though some traders still note that the ES is yet to fully pare back those losses, and reclaim the 2785 level. The risk tone was once again firm on Friday, until headlines hit stating that Special Counsel Mueller had indicted 13 Russians and three entities with regards to interference in the 2016 Presidential Election. At the time, stock indices were losing steam, with ES March’18 contract struggling to negotiate the 2750 handle, and the news brought out the sellers. The indictments contained no allegations that an American citizen was knowingly involved in US election meddling, and after stocks skidded lower into negative territory, buyers emerged around the key 2725 level, and stocks once again found themselves in positive territory, though the social media names weighed on the Nasdaq, which finished red.

subject: NOTICE: Please see below the desk and market closures for Monday’s President Day Holiday
content:
Desk

The desk will operate a normal service on Monday until 1800GMT/1200CST, upon which the desk will close and then re-open later at 2200GMT/1600CST for the beginning on the Asia-Pacific closure given the US market closures

Market Closures

CME Electronic Equity, Interest Rate, Energy & Metals – Trading Halt between 1200CST/1800GMT and 1700CST/2300GMT

CME Chicago Pit Trade – Closed

NYSE – Closed

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian bourses got off to a firm start to the week with the Nikkei 225 supported by domestic trade data
content:
• Asian bourses got off to a firm start to the week with the Nikkei 225 supported by domestic trade data
  • In FX markets, USD remains a key driving force after recouping opening losses ahead of the EU open
  • Today sees a lack of tier 1 highlights with US participants away from market for President’s Day

ASIA

Asian bourses get off to a firm start to the week, with the ASX 200 (+0.6%), Nikkei 225 (+2.0%) and KOSPI (+0.4%) trading with modest gains. ASX 200 has been supported by strength observed in financial, subsequently offsetting the losses in Woodside Petroleum (-6%) following AUD 2.5bln capital raising. South Korean participants have return from their elongated break to catch up with last weeks global equity recovery. Nikkei 225 has been buoyed by encouraging trade data, whereby exports rose for a 14th consecutive month. Markets have been somewhat quiet given the Lunar New Year holiday with Chinese markets out of action until Wednesday (HK reopens tomorrow)

Very quiet session in the fixed income space with Japanese yields relatively flat across the curve. Elsewhere, Aussie yields have shown a slight bull flattening bias today. AU-US 10 spreads (+0.1bps) continue to remain at the tightest levels since 1998.

Japanese Trade Balance (JPY)(Jan) Y/Y -943B vs. Exp. -1,002B (Prev. 359B)
Adjusted Trade Balance (JPY)(Jan) Y/Y 370bln vs. Exp. 140bln (Prev. 90bln)
Exports (Jan) Y/Y 12.2% Exp. 10.3% (Prev. 9.3%)
Import (Jan) Y/Y 7.9% Exp. 8.3% (Prev. 14.9%)


UK/EU

UK's Brexit trade deal with the EU will not be finalised before exit day, warns EU Negotiator, Verhofstadt. Instead there will be an "annex" inside the withdrawal agreement which will set out what a future relationship might look like, to be thrashed out during the transitional period while current rules remain in place. (Telegraph)

ECB’s Rimsevics was detained by the anti-graft bureau, in a flurry of actions by officials with the financial regulator imposing payment restrictions on third-biggest lender ABLV Bank AS. (Newswires)

UK Rightmove House Price Index (Jan) M/M 0.8% (Prev. 0.7%). (Newswires)

IHS Survey: UK Feb Household Finance Index 42.2 (Prev. 42.9); lowest since July. 60% of households see BoE hiking rates in 6-months (Prev. 45%).

S&P affirms Hungary at BBB-, outlook positive. Fitch upgrades Greece to B (Prev. B-), Outlook positive.DBRS affirms Belgium at AA(High); stable trend. DBRS affirms Ireland at A(High); stable trend

FX

A familiar story for the USD for much of the session, which had been on the back foot against its major counterparts after slipping through the 89.00 figure, potentially setting another retest around key support at 88.25-30. However, the greenback (+0.6%) did catch a late bid to make a move back above 89.00. Commodity currencies had been tracking oil prices higher today with WTI making a break above USD 62, largely owing to the risk tone. Eyes on AUD this week, with RBA minutes due out tomorrow, alongside key wage data later this week. Cross-related buying in AUD/NZD kept AUD above 0.79 for now.

Across Asia FX, the SGD will come into focus later today with the finance minister set to announce the latest budget at 0730GMT. Expectations are for the finance minister to hike the GST by 1-2%, which some suggest may increase speculation that the MAS could potentially tighten monetary policy in April. The appreciation in the THB seems to have had a dampening effect on Thailand’s growth in Q4, as the latest figures missed analyst estimates, which resulted in USD/THB pulling off the lows.

COMMODITIES

Brent and WTI crude futures advanced in Asian trade with prices supported by the improvement in risk sentiment as the latter breached above USD 62/bbl. Elsewhere, earlier gains in the precious dissipated amid the recovery in the USD index. 

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (16 Feb) 975 (Prev. 975)
- Baker Hughes Oil Rig Count (16 Feb) 798 (Prev. 791)
- Baker Hughes Gas Rig Count (16 Feb) 177 (Prev. 184)

OPEC and Russia are considering options for cooperation after 2018, according to UAE. (Newswires)

Late Friday: US Commerce Department mulling 7.7% aluminium tariff, to recommend 23.5% tariff on all aluminium products from China, Russia, Venezuela and Vietnam. (Newswires)


US

EQUITIES: SPX +0.1% at 2739, DJI +0.1% at 25281, NDX -0.1% at 6785

Top sectors: Healthcare +0.9%, Telecoms +0.9%, Utilities +0.9%
Bottom sectors: Cons Disc -0.3%, Materials -0.1% Energy -0.1%

SPX prints its sixth straight day of gains, as traders question whether the recent VIX-inspired sell-off can actually be considered anything close to “market turmoil,” though some traders still note that the ES is yet to fully pare back those losses, and reclaim the 2785 level. The risk tone was once again firm on Friday, until headlines hit stating that Special Counsel Mueller had indicted 13 Russians and three entities with regards to interference in the 2016 Presidential Election. At the time, stock indices were losing steam, with ES March’18 contract struggling to negotiate the 2750 handle, and the news brought out the sellers. The indictments contained no allegations that an American citizen was knowingly involved in US election meddling, and after stocks skidded lower into negative territory, buyers emerged around the key 2725 level, and stocks once again found themselves in positive territory, though the social media names weighed on the Nasdaq, which finished red.

The US Treasury complex was immune to headlines that Special Counsel Mueller had indicted 13 Russians and three entities for meddling in the 2016 US Presidential Election. The curve was slightly higher pre-market, though buyers emerged for a second day, with no specific news catalyst. Some had rationalised the moves by suggesting that US Treasuries were oversold in many places, from a technical perspective. Either way, the net impact was narrowing in major curve spreads (2s10s -c4bps, 2s30s -c3bps, hough 5s30s was up slightly)

US Special Counsel Mueller has indicted 13 Russian nationals and three entities over conspiracy to defraud the US. Additionally, US Deputy AG Rosenstein says there is no allegation in today's indictments that an American was knowingly involved in US election meddling. (Newswires)
